text:
Section #0 - Multiplier.
The multiplier is a value which impacts your overall score, to reflect the number of people impacted by your system.
To continue, type 'Ok'

How large is the target cohort for your decision system?
These are the people your system makes decisions, predictions or classifications about. Include the entire population, not the subset of people who might receive an unfavorable or harmful result.

C.recommendation:
Try it with fewer people, first.
You could trial your system with a small target cohort (Beta release). Communicate extensively with the cohort. Observe what goes wrong. Be prepared to stop or intervene if things are going badly. You could also consider a staged roll-out of your system - break down your release rather than doing it all at once. Provide sufficient time between roll-out milestones to adjust and course-correct if unexpected issue crop up.

D.recommendation:
Try it with fewer people, first.
You could trial your system with a small target cohort (Beta release). Communicate extensively with the cohort. Observe what goes wrong. Be prepared to stop or intervene if things are going badly. You could also consider a staged roll-out of your system - break down your release rather than doing it all at once. Provide sufficient time between roll-out milestones to adjust and course-correct if unexpected issue crop up.

You could also consider a staged roll-out of your system - break down your release rather than doing it all at once. Provide sufficient time between roll-out milestones to adjust and course-correct if unexpected issue crop up.

You could also consider a staged roll-out of your system - break down your release rather than doing it all at once. Provide sufficient time between roll-out milestones to adjust and course-correct if unexpected issue crop up.

text: How is your target cohort distributed geographically?

Section #1 - Cohort scan.
Estimates the relative vulnerability of your target cohort.
To continue, type 'Ok'

Is your target cohort economically vulnerable?
Look at average earning rates of your country if you aren't sure where your demographic sits overall.

Is your target cohort psychologically vulnerable?
Are they likely to suffer from mental health issues, self-harm, or to have their capacity to work, study, or pursue their goals impacted by debilitating mental illness?

Is your target cohort vulnerable to coercive control?
Consider parents controlling LGBTQI children. Jaime Spears. Elder abuse. Intimate partner abuse. Technological coercion or control.

Is your target cohort over-policed or over-surveilled?
Are they more likely than the average population in any aspect of their lives to be targeted by police, social services or surveillance systems?

Is your target cohort technologically vulnerable?
Will they have more difficulty navigating technological systems than average? Poor digital literacy? Do they have a higher rate of visual impairments or other disabilities which would compound this?

Does your target cohort have robust internet access?
Is your target cohort in a remote area with poor infrastructure? Exposed to download or over-limit fees? Access on 1 or more devices? Internet sharing or have own service? Physically at-risk if they try to access public internet? Are they accessing the internet from cellular networks, NBN, ADSL, Broadband, other?

Section #2 - System scan.
Estimates the resiliance of your system and it's ability to observe and recover from failure cases.
To continue, type 'Ok'

Does your decision system operate as part of a competitive marketplace, or are you the only provider of the specific service, platform, resource or goods?
Consider the viability and discoverability of alternatives or competitor systems. Consider network effects, brand visibility, feature parity, cost of adoption, etc.

Is your decision system mandatory or optional?
Mandatory systems will be mostly government applications; paying taxes, rent, complying with judicial hearings or prison sentences, etc.

Is your decision system opt-in or opt-out?
Does the target cohort actively choose to participate or add themselves? Or are they included by default and have to actively remove themselves?

How visible or discoverable is it that the target cohort has been opted-into the system?
Do you notify them, is the operation of your system visible, or do they have to find it in a setting or lodge their own query?

A.recommendation:
System visibility
If your target cohort is automatically opted into your system, you must ensure that this is clearly explained, and allow them to opt-out easily through the same interface.

B.recommendation:
System visibility
If your target cohort is automatically opted into your system, you must ensure that this is clearly explained, and allow them to opt-out easily through the same interface.

C.recommendation:
System visibility
If your target cohort is automatically opted into your system, you must ensure that this is clearly explained, and allow them to opt-out easily through the same interface.

text: How difficult is it to opt out?

A.recommendation:
System usability
If your target cohort is automatically opted into your system, you must ensure that this is clearly explained, and allow them to opt-out easily through the same interface.

B.recommendation:
System usability
If your target cohort is automatically opted into your system, you must ensure that this is clearly explained, and allow them to opt-out easily through the same interface.

C.recommendation:
System usability
If your target cohort is automatically opted into your system, you must ensure that this is clearly explained, and allow them to opt-out easily through the same interface.

text:
How perpetual is opting out?
Does the user preference remain for system upgrades or migrations, normal use, etc?

B.text: Lasts forever (but periodically asked to opt in)

C.recommendation:
System visibility
If the target cohort is added back into the system automatically, you must alert them to the fact and and allow them to opt-out easily through the same interface.

text:
Can you turn your decision system off instantly if something goes wrong?
Can you do this with one click, or do you have to deploy code to take it down?

No.recommendation:
Graceful degredation.
Add a feature flag or other automation process that allows you to turn it off in production, if issues arise. Consider, for example, building a simple business logic version as a fall-back, to keep the system running.

text: Does your system always output a classification, prediction, or decision?

Yes.recommendation:
Phone a (human friend).
Consider looping in a person where the machine confidence is low, or when production data changes significantly.

text:
Do you provide a record of the system decision for individuals, including a unique ID that can be traced in your system log?
For their reference and for looking up that decision later on. This could be on-screen, email, PDF, etc.

No.recommendation:
System auditability.
For system decisions or classifications, especially high stakes ones, provide a record of the system decison (email, PDF, text message, etc), including a unique ID that can be traced in your system log.

text:
Does your decision system request meaningful consent, including a clear explanation of the uses of data and ramifications of providing consent?
Note if your consent request is tokenistic, confusing or deliberately misleading you should answer No

No.recommendation:
GDPR
It is crucial to ensure that people are willing and informed participants in the system. A good consent request is clear, interpretable and contextual.

text: Have you performed user testing to assess the usability of your consent section?

No.recommendation:
System usability
User testing on the text and presentation of your consent request can significantly improve usability and interpretability.

text: Do you provide a mechanism to allow individuals to revoke consent to use their data?

No.recommendation:
GDPR compliance
Allow target cohort to revoke consent to use their data. If they can do this but only within a fixed timeline, make sure that timeline is communicated in the interface.

text:
Do you provide any visual or text-based explanation of your automated system decision on the decision interface?
This could be in the form of displaying results for similar candidates, or identifying which feature had a strong impact on their outcome.

No.recommendation:
System transparency
Add decision explanations to help your target cohort understand the system. Consider highlighting features which contributed to the result, and exposing system confidence or uncertainty, especially for high-stakes predictions.

text:
Can your target cohort request a decision review?
If they don't understand or agree with the automated decision, is there an existing channel or feedback mechanism for them to request explanation? Are explanations planned and available (e.g. you've designed or planned for them before they are requested)? Note this doesn't include generic feedback mechanisms.

No.recommendation:
Plan for failure
Improve your risk score by allowing the target cohort to flag questions and concerns, and to request a human review of their decision. Make a plan for how you will conduct decision review. Think through which scenarios will justify a change and which ones won't and work through how to explain these outcomes clearly.

text: What is the probability that decision review will reverse or change the decision?
On-average how much effort is required by your target cohort to lodge a request for decision review?

B.recommendation:
Decison review
Requiring a significant effort to reverse a system decision risks further harm. Try to simplify up the decision review process.

C.recommendation:
Decison review
Requiring a significant effort to reverse a system decision risks further harm. Try to simplify the decision review process.

text: On-average how long will your decision review process take?

B.recommendation:
Decison review
Making people wait a significant period of time to reverse a system decision risks further harm. Speed up the decision review process to improve your score.

C.recommendation:
Decison review
Making people wait a significant period of time to reverse a system decision risks further harm. Speed up the decision review process to improve your score.

text:
Section #3 - Maslov's Hierarchy of needs.
Slightly updated for the modern era. Compares the likelihood of harm with no intervention (if your system didn't exist) to the likelihood of this harm occurring as a result of your intervention.
So if your target cohort are all drinking toxic water and your system reduces the number of people getting toxic water, you're reducing the probability of this harm because of the high base rate.
To continue, type 'Ok'

Physiological needs
What's the probability that decisions, classifications, predictions or interventions from your automated decision system will directly, negatively impact your target cohort's Physiological needs? (Air, water, food, shelter, sleep, reproduction)

Safety needs
What's the probability that decisions, classifications, predictions or interventions from your automated decision system will directly, negatively impact your target cohort's Safety needs? (Personal security, employment, resources, health, property, internet access, information access, information security)

Love and belonging needs
What's the probability that decisions, classifications, predictions or interventions from your automated decision system will directly, negatively impact your target cohort's Love and belonging needs? (Friendship, intimacy, family, sense of connection, access to online communities)

Esteem needs
What's the probability that decisions, classifications, predictions or interventions from your automated decision system will directly, negatively impact your target cohort's Esteem needs? (Respect, self-esteem, status, recognition, strength, freedom)

Self-actualisation needs?
What's the probability that decisions, classifications, predictions or interventions from your automated decision system will directly, negatively impact your target cohort's Self-actualisation needs? (Desire to become the most one can be)

T1.title: The white walkers
T1.text: This territory belongs to the undead. Turn around! Don't venture here, where packs of spiders roam. You will harm people and almost certainly won't be able unpick those harms.

T2.title: Fields of thorns
T2.text: This path is paved with dangers and misery, and the long night casts it's shadow on this quest. There might be ways to win, but they'll be risky. Can you reinforce your troups, or find another path?

T3.title: Winter is coming
T3.text: What do you know of fear? You may not have felt the bite of winter's sting, but all the more reason to plan for it's hardships.

T4.title: The stronghold
T4.text: You're shoring up your castle walls - but there are still plenty of opportunities to stumble and impale yourself, or someone else.

T5.title: Castles in the sky
T5.text: You've found the highest ground of all! You're working on a problem space with a surprisingly low risk of harm! Don't become complacent, though.
